attributes.title: Visual hallucinations, pareidolia-proneness, anxiety and depression in a non-clinical sample

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Visual Hallucinations, pareidolia-proneness, anxiety and depression in a non-clinical sample

sample.value: A proposed total of 212 participants will be recruited in the current study. This is because as medium correlations are expected (r = .30), 212 participants would sufficient at finding this association with 80% confidence within a window of plus or minus .10 (Schonbrodt & Perugini, 2013). Participants must be aged 18 or over and have a good understanding of English. They also must not have visual impairments, a history of neurological illness or injury, are a history of mental health problems diagnosed by a doctor.

analyses.value: Bivariate correlations will be calculated for all variables (testing Hypotheses 1a to 1e).  Hierarchical regression analyses will then be conducted, with frequency of VH-like  experiences as the outcome variable and with demographic variables (age, gender,  ethnicity), anxiety, and depression scores entered as predictor variables in Step One.  Then in Step Two, number of hits made on the Face Pareidolia Task will be entered as a  predictor variable. If the results of this regression are consistent with a mediating effect  of pareidolia-proneness, a mediation analysis, using the Process macro in IBM SPSS 26  will be employed, to tests hypotheses 2a and 2b.

dependent.value:
As well as a set of demographic factors, we will measure two predictor variables, one  outcome variable and one mediator variable. The predictor variables will be scores of  anxiety and scores of depression. The outcome variable will be visual hallucination-like experiences, whilst the mediator variable will be face-pareidolia proneness. The entire  will be implemented online via Qualtrics. 
 
 In order to measure participant’s anxiety and depression, the Depression, Anxiety and  Stress Scale (DASS-21) will be used. This is a 21-item questionnaire that requires to judge  how each item applies to them whilst recalling on their experiences from the previous  seven days. Items are rated on a 4-point Likert scale (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995). 
 
 The visual subscale of the Multi-Modality Unusual Sensory Experiences questionnaire  (MUSEQ) will be used to measure visual hallucination-like experiences. The visual  subscale of the MUSEQ consists of 8 items whilst the original MUSEQ consists of 43 items  (Mitchell et al., 2017). Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale and examples of the items  include “There have been times when my eyes have played tricks on me” and “There  have been times when I looked at an object and it transformed itself before my eyes into  something else”. 
 
 The Face Pareidolia Detection Task (Smailes et al., 2020) will be used to measure  pareidolia-proneness in participants. The task consists of 36 trials and requires  participants to decide whether face pareidolia was or was not present in the image; in 24  trails participants are presented with an image that contains face pareidolia and the in  remaining 12 trails an  image that does not contain face pareidolia is presented.  Pareidolia-proneness will be measured in terms of the number of hits participants make  on the task (i.e., how often they detect that a face pareidolia was present in the 24  images that do contain a face pareidolia).

hypothesis.value:
The current study is yet to receive ethical approval. This pre-registration is being created and submitted to meet the demands of a module on the researcher’s Master’s course. The proposed aims, hypotheses, methods (i.e. participants, materials, variables), and analyses may be subject to change based on potential revision during ethical approval. Any changes will be re-submitted

The current study aims to test if the association between anxiety and frequency of VHlike experiences is mediated by pareidolia-proneness. It also aims to examine whether the association between depression and frequency of VH-like experiences is mediated by pareidolia-proneness. The study also aims to address the limitations of the previous literature and validate the relationship between VH, anxiety and depression. This will be done by using different, well-established measures compared to the previous studies when determining levels of anxiety, depression and VH-like experiences. The current research proposes to investigate these relationships within a non-clinical sample. as there is a clear lack of research within the area on non-clinical populations, despite non-clinical samples allowing a greater understanding of clinical populations. 
 
The proposed study has minor/ secondary hypotheses in that positive correlations will be found between scores of 1a) VH and face pareidolia-proneness; 1b) VH and anxiety; 1c) VH and depression; 1d) anxiety and face pareidolia-proneness; 1e) depression and face pareidolia-proneness. The main hypothesis of the proposed study are that 2a) face pareidolia-proneness will mediate the relationship between scores of anxiety and VH, and 2b) face pareidolia-proneness will mediate the relationship between scores of depression and VH. 

The current study proposes the question “Does face pareidolia-proneness mediate the effect of both anxiety and depression on visual hallucinations in a non-clinical sample?”

attributes.title: Effectively dealing with idle time at work
attributes.description: In a vignette study, we want to examine different strategies for dealing with idle time at work dependet on different working conditions. Therefore, we choose two scenarios in which idle time occurs and job demands and resources are manipulated.

q1.value: Vignette study on proactive and adaptive strategy use when dealing with idle time at work

q3.value: Idle time is defined as “involuntary downtime during which in-role tasks cannot be done” (Brodsky & Amabile, 2018, p. 3). In our vignette study, we examine how employees are dealing with idle time at work. The goal of our study is to examine strategy use in different working environments. Therefore, we create two different scenarios in which idle time occurs and ask participants what they would do in these exact situations. In the work scenarios, we manipulate job demands and resources to see how different working conditions affect strategy use. In our theoretical model we categorise strategies as proactive (taking charge, trying to influence changing environment) or as adaptive (reacting to changing environment, adapting one's own behaviour).

q4.value:
H1: We expect that in the high autonomy condition (job resource) strategy use (proactive and adaptive) is stronger than in the low autonomy condition.
H2: We expect the strongest use of proactive strategies in the high autonomy/high workload condition compared to any other condition. 
H3: We expect the strongest use of adaptive strategies in the high autonomy/low workload condition compared to any other condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We divide our study into two parts. The first part examines the main effect of autonomy on strategy use and the second part examines the interaction effect of autonomy and workload on strategy use.
Therefore, we create two different work environments which include different types of idle time. In the first work environment (study part 1) we only manipulate autonomy (e.g., can decide which task to do when; high vs. low, 2x1 conditions, 2 vignettes). The first work environment is a typical sale situation where no customers arrive (occurrence of idle time). The lack of customers includes a lack of work demands.
In the second work environment (study part 2) a project manager can not continue working because of a lack of information (occurrence of idle time). In this work environment, we manipulate work demands (e.g., has a lot of work to do to finish the project, tight deadline) and autonomy (each high vs. low, 2x2 conditions, 4 vignettes). In this scenario, the lack of information does not necessarily include a lack of work demands. 
After reading the vignette each participant is asked to describe what they would do in this specific work situation. Therefore, they are asked to write down three behavioural strategies.
On the next pages of the study, participants are asked to rate the likelihood to engage in specific behavioural strategies based on scales from prior research on similar constructs. 
For a manipulation check, we ask participants to answer if the scenario included any work constraints and if they felt like there was idle time. At last, we ask them to evaluate autonomy and workload in their vignette.
The vignettes are attached below. Each participant only reads one vignette. 
We have previously created a code scheme, in which strategies from prior research on similar constructs are categorised as proactive or adaptive by four independent raters. The code scheme is attached below.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one scenario each via the applied online survey tool.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The data collection is part of a bigger dataset. The other questions concern age stereotypes at the workplace and are therefore independent from our data collection.

q13.value: We plan to collect data from >600 participants resulting in a minimum of 100 participants per vignette.

q15.value: We only stop the data collection if we collected data from 100 participants per scenario.

question.value:
In each vignette we describe a situation in which an employee experiences a specific constraint and following idle time. 
In two vignettes we manipulated autonomy (2x1). 
Vignette 1 - high autonomy: The person in the scenario is free to design their work and choose which tasks to do when and how.
Vignette 2 - low autonomy: The person in the scenario is restricted in their work design and has to follow strict rules which tasks to do when and how.
In the four following vignettes we manipulated autonomy (the same way as in the first two scenarios) and additionally we manipulated demands (2x2).
Vignette 3 - high autonomy/high demands: The person in the scenario is free to design their work and choose which tasks to do when and how and has to finish their project until the next morning and there is still a lot of work to do.
Vignette 4 - low autonomy/high demands: The person in the scenario is restricted in their work design and has to follow strict rules which tasks to do when and how and has to finish their project until the next morning and there is still a lot of work to do.
Vignette 5 - low autonomy/low demands: The person in the scenario is restricted in their work design and has to follow strict rules which tasks to do when and how and has to finish the project at some time and until then there are just few tasks left. 
Vignette 6 - high autonomy/low demands: The person in the scenario is free to design their work and choose which tasks to do when and how and has to finish the project at some time and until then there are just few tasks left.

We measure proactive and adaptive strategies by asking participants to write down behavioural strategies. These ideas will be categorised as proactive/adaptive by two independent raters using the code scheme. 
Afterwards, participants are asked to rate the likelihood to engage in specific behavioural strategies based on scales from prior research on similar constructs. These scales include: proactive behaviour, adaptive behaviour, work stretching, job crafting, recovery experiences, cyberloafing, microbreak activities and behavioural strategies for idle time (found in a prior study). 
For a manipulation check, we ask participants to answer if the scenario included any work constraints and idle time. At last, we ask them to evaluate autonomy and workload in their vignette.
As control variables and for describing our sample, we ask participants about their gender, age, working experience, weekly working hours, perceived idle time in their jobs, as well as proactive personality.
Scales are attached below.
For the scales measured in the second part of the study we build means for constructs with more than one item.

For testing the first hypothesis, we compute a MANOVA with autonomy (high vs. low) as the between-subject factor.
For testing the other hypotheses we compute a MANOVA with the combination of autonomy and workload (high autonomy/high workload vs. high autonomy/low workload vs. low autonomy/high workload vs. low autonomy/low workload) as the between-subject factor. To specify significant differences we compute post-hoc t-tests for independent groups.
The dependent variables for every hypothesis are the categorised strategies and the behavioural strategy scales. 
As manipulation check we compare means of constraints, idle time, autonomy and workload rated in each vignette.

q20.value:
In preparation for coding the strategies the participants write down, four independent raters categorise proactive and adaptive strategies from a literature search on idle time and strategy use at work. After this independent rating process, strategies with no agreement on a category are discussed together within the group of raters. Afterwards, missing strategies were discussed. If there is no possibility to match them with an existing strategy, they are added to the coding scheme. 
The strategies in the coding scheme resemble the ones in the behavioural strategy scales.

attributes.title: The link between violent video games and aggression: Using a public data set to evaluate the relationship

summary.value:
The purpose of this research is to use a preexisting data set to explore differing and more theoretically sound media psychology research practices. In the original article (Pryzbylski & Weinstein, 2019), there were numerous methodological and statistical decisions made that obscured the results presented (Bushman & Anderson, In Review). These kinds of mistakes can be harmful when we talk about science acceptance (Prot & Anderson, 2020), and by presenting this information in this way, we know that it can ruin trust in scientific discourse. 
 We believe that by using this fairly robust dataset and incorporating more appropriate methodological and statistical approaches, we can establish the best practices one should take when researching media violence effects. We will address our concerns about the original analyses (poor measures of aggression and of violent gameplay, as well as inappropriately controlling for trait aggression while assessing media violence effects on aggressive behavior) in a separate manuscript to be submitting to the original journal, but the manuscript to be prepared based on this preregistration will use the dataset to establish a course of best practices when looking at media effects. We intend to address the following:

-	Creating more valid measures of aggression, both by using the Buss Perry scales provided, as well as exploring how the measure used in the original article (the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire) can potentially be used as a way to measure aggressive behavior. We intend to conduct exploratory factor analyses to see how the SDQ maps onto more valid constructs of aggression. We will also use certain items from the SDQ (determined both by the standard definitions of aggressive behavior, cognition, and affect, as well as results from factor analyses) combined with items from Buss Perry subscales, to see if more valid and theoretically consistent measures of aggression can be created. 
-	Create new measures of violent content in the video games listed by participants, and thereby of violent video game exposure. The original authors used game ratings (the ESRB and PEGI ratings boards respectively) to determine the amount of violent content participants recorded playing. However, we know that simply using such ratings as a measure of violent content does not adequately capture the amount of violent content players are exposed to (Anderson et. al, 2017; Busching et al., 2015). We have trained research assistants to go through the database of recorded games, watch gameplay clips, and rate the violent content based on methods previously established to be more sensitive than simply using the game’s parental ratings (Anderson et. al, 2017). They currently (February 2020) are doing the ratings. We will run multiple analyses comparing the original use of ratings to evaluate violent content, with this more sensitive method, to test whether using more direct questions and evaluations of violent content are more valid than using game ratings, as has been found in previous work. 
-	We also intend to use structural equational modeling (SEM) to test the relationships between violent gameplay, aggressive behavior, and other mediating (e.g., trait hostility, trait anger) and moderating variables (e.g., gender and age). 
-	We also will include a list of best practices to engage in whenever analyzing media effects data. We will walk through a list of steps (outlined below) that will show how and why some of these basic steps are necessary to begin any statistical analyses and should be reported in all future published manuscripts (perhaps as Supplemental Materials:
1.	Check for errors and mindless responding for example:
a.	Look for impossible scores on each variable (e.g., a “7” on a 1 to 5 scale)
b.	Compute standard deviations within each participant for multi-item scales
2.	Check distributions and alphas of key variables:
a.	Use box plots to reveal asymmetric distributions and outliers (as defined by Tukey)
b.	Use means & standard deviations to find data points more than 3 standard deviations from mean
c.	Use Ladder of Powers to transform badly skewed data
d.	Check standard deviations of each item in multi-item scales. If very different, consider standardizing items before combining into a summed (or averaged) scale

References

Anderson, C. A., Suzuki, K., Swing, E. L., Groves, C. L., Gentile, D. A., Prot, S., ... & Jelic, M. (2017). Media violence and other aggression risk factors in seven nations. Personality and social psychology bulletin, 43(7), 986-998.

Busching, R., Gentile, D. G., Krahé, B., Möller, I., Khoo, A., Walsh, D. A., & Anderson, C. A. (2015). Testing the reliability and validity of different measures of violent video game use in the USA, Singapore, and Germany. Psychology of Popular Media Culture, 4, 97-111.  

Bushman, B. & Anderson, C.A. (In Review). How to obtain a null media violence effect. Perspectives in Psychological Science. 

Prot, S., & Anderson, C. A. (2020). Science denial: Psychological processes underlying denial of science-based medical practices (pp. 24-37). In A. Lavorgna & A. DiRonco (Eds.), Medical Misinformation and Social Harm inNon-science-based Health Practices. New York: Routledge.

Przybylski, A. K., & Weinstein, N. (2019). Violent video game engagement is not associated with adolescents' aggressive behaviour: evidence from a registered report. Royal Society open science, 6(2), 171474.

a.	Use box plots to reveal asymmetric distributions and outliers (as defined by Tukey)
b.	Use means & standard deviations to find data points more than 3 standard deviations from mean
c.	Use Ladder of Powers to transform badly skewed data
d.	Check standard deviations of each item in multi-item scales. If very different, consider standardizing items before combining into a summed (or averaged) scale

References

Anderson, C. A., Suzuki, K., Swing, E. L., Groves, C. L., Gentile, D. A., Prot, S., ... & Jelic, M. (2017). Media violence and other aggression risk factors in seven nations. Personality and social psychology bulletin, 43(7), 986-998.

Busching, R., Gentile, D. G., Krahé, B., Möller, I., Khoo, A., Walsh, D. A., & Anderson, C. A. (2015). Testing the reliability and validity of different measures of violent video game use in the USA, Singapore, and Germany. Psychology of Popular Media Culture, 4, 97-111.  

Bushman, B. & Anderson, C.A. (In Review). How to obtain a null media violence effect. Perspectives in Psychological Science. 

Prot, S., & Anderson, C. A. (2020). Science denial: Psychological processes underlying denial of science-based medical practices (pp. 24-37). In A. Lavorgna & A. DiRonco (Eds.), Medical Misinformation and Social Harm inNon-science-based Health Practices. New York: Routledge.

Przybylski, A. K., & Weinstein, N. (2019). Violent video game engagement is not associated with adolescents' aggressive behaviour: evidence from a registered report. Royal Society open science, 6(2), 171474.

attributes.title: A survey about what individuals will notice, and when

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: A survey of what individuals will notice, and when: A comparison of different legal populations

other.value: Like Levin & Angelone (2008), we will compare beliefs regarding what individuals will notice to the rates of actual noticing (and inattentional blindness) that were found in the original studies, as the scenarios are based off real studies where rates of inattentional blindness have been reported. Therefore, we can determine whether there is an overestimation of visual detection which has been found in previous research (Levin & Angelone, 2008; Ortega et al., 2018).

sample.value: We will recruit up to 100 participants from each population.

analyses.value:
We will report the means and frequencies for each group (i.e. lawyers and members of the public) on the above 4 factors, as well as demographic information. 

We will conduct analyses (ANOVA, chi square) to determine whether there are differences across the groups in regards to age and gender. Demographic information for both groups will be reported (age, gender, cultural background, and for lawyers, their work history).

Chi-square analyses will also be conducted comparing responses to the scenarios of what individuals will notice (dichotomous: will notice vs. will not notice) across the different populations. Similarly, for the questions regarding beliefs about whether individuals would be more, just as, or less likely to notice something under different circumstances, we will run chi-square analyses to compare these beliefs across the different groups. Furthermore, we will compare the groups on their knowledge and familiarity with inattentional blindness, and their anecdotal experiences with inattentional blindness. 

The survey provides opportunities for participants to freely respond. We will code the qualitative data provided through these responses, and report them within the results.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete the entire study.

dependent.value:
This is a survey study in which we will measure the following:

1. Beliefs of what individuals will notice in situations where inattentional blindness may occur (based on the existing literature into inattentional blindness)
2. Beliefs about whether individuals would be more likely, just as likely, or less likely to notice something under different circumstances (based on the existing literature into inattentional blindness)
3. Knowledge about inattentional blindness (familiarity with the term, any studies of inattentional blindness, specifically the Simons & Chabris [1999] study)
4. Anecdotal experience of inattentional blindness (whether they can reflect on a time where they experienced inattentional blindness, and the details of that experience. Additionally, whether they believe anything can be done to make someone more likely to notice something when their attention is focused elsewhere)

conditions.value:
So far, we have two populations that interact within the legal system (lawyers, and members of the general public), and we will compare these two populations in their beliefs around what individuals will notice, the factors they believe will influence noticing, their knowledge of inattentional blindness, and their anecdotal experience of inattentional blindness. 

We are currently in the process of applying for police officers to also complete the survey. If this does eventuate, we will have a third comparison group. If not, we will only have the two as per the current pre-registration.

hypothesis.value:
This survey measures beliefs held by lawyers and members of the general public (i.e. potential jurors) regarding what people would notice in real-world scenarios, and what factors individuals believe affect what people would notice. 

Previous studies have explored beliefs about visual detection (Levin & Angelone, 2008) and beliefs about whether individuals will notice unexpected events (Simons & Chabris, 2011, 2012). However, it is important to extend this research to look at beliefs regarding visual detection within legal populations. This is important because there are many real-world situations of inattentional blindness that are legally relevant. An individual failing to notice something may be sued, or face negligence charges. Therefore these individuals may be deemed to be legally responsible when they have failed to see something (Jaeger et al., 2017). Beliefs about inattentional blindness and what individuals will notice may also extend to how individuals are treated within the legal system. For example, beliefs that lawyers have about what individuals will notice may affect how they approach legal cases, and how they prepare and defend clients. Beliefs that members of the general population have about what individuals will notice may affect their legal decision-making as jurors. Therefore, we will explore beliefs and compare beliefs among lawyers and members of the general population about what individuals will notice (and the factors that influence what individuals will notice), using legally relevant scenarios derived from the inattentional blindness literature (e.g. driving, medicine, witnesses). We will also assess participants' knowledge and anecdotal experiences of inattentional blindness, as it has been previously suggested that one solution to reducing misconceptions regarding inattentional blindness is allowing individuals to experience it for themselves (Hyman, 2016). Therefore, determining whether individuals can reflect on their own personal experiences of inattentional blindness may be useful in rectifying misconceptions within the legal field. 

We hypothesise that the two current groups (lawyers and general population) will differ in age and gender. We expect lawyers will be significantly older than our general public group (because the general public group will comprise of introductory psychology students who have not yet learnt about inattentional blindness during classes). We also expect that lawyers will have a more even split of males and females compared to the general public group.

The survey is exploratory. We do not have any clear or directional hypotheses regarding differences within the populations in their beliefs about what individuals will notice, or the factors that they believe make individuals more, just as, or less likely to notice something. Previous studies of beliefs regarding eyewitness memory have demonstrated that different legal populations differ in their beliefs regarding some eyewitness factors, but not all (Granhag et al., 2005; Jiang & Luo, 2016; Kask, 2011). Therefore, we expect some differences may emerge across the groups regarding beliefs about noticing, but we do not know for what items and scenarios these groups may differ.  

Additionally, given that neither of the two populations are given training into inattentional blindness, we do not believe there will be differences in their knowledge of inattentional blindness. There may be differences in their ability to think of examples of situations where inattentional blindness may occur, if lawyers have defended or worked on cases where inattentional blindness may have occurred in the past.

attributes.title: The effects of absolutely-compared to relatively-defined intensity walking on physical activity outcomes: a systematic review with meta analysis
attributes.description: The primary question is to determine whether differences exist between intensity prescribed or measuredusing absolute or relative, during walking in human participants. And if so, what is the magnitude ofdifference, specifically at moderate and vigorous intensities.

q1.value: The effects of absolutely-compared to relatively-defined intensity walking on physical activity outcomes: asystematic review with meta analysis

q2.value: Ashley Warner, Dr. Grant Abt, Prof. Natalie Vanicek, Amanda Benson, Dr Tony Myers

q3.value: The primary question is to determine whether differences exist between intensity prescribed or measured using absolute or relative, during walking in human participants. And if so, what is the magnitude of difference, specifically at moderate and vigorous intensities.

q4.value: If there are differences between relative and absolute intensity, then relative intensity will be more accurate in defining exercise intensity.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A narrative synthesis of the outcome measures. The intention is to undertake a meta analysis of the data if the intervention and outcome methodology are not too heterogenous.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
This systematic review with meta analysis will follow the outlined search criteria below:

Sources that will be searched are:
CINAHL complete
MEDLINE
PRE-MEDLINE
SPORTDiscus 
Scopus
Web of Science

Restrictions include:
English language
2000-2019 publication period
Adult population 18-69 years old
Human 

Searches will be re-run before final analysis and any further studies identified, meeting the inclusion criteria, will be included in final analysis.

The search criteria is as follows:
(step* OR walk* OR stride* OR striding OR "physical activity") N3 (speed* OR pace OR intensity ORcadence) ) AND ( pedometer* OR actigraph* OR accelerometry OR "activity monitor*" OR "heart rate*" ORvo2max OR vo2reserve OR "oxygen consumption" OR "wearable device*" OR "wearable electronic device*"OR "wearable device" OR "wearable tech*" OR "fitness track*" OR "activity track*")


Inclusion criteria: Healthy adults aged 18-69 years old  
Exclusion criteria: Non human species, elderly populations over 70 years old, clinical populations.

Types of study that will be included are:
randomised controlled trials, cross-sectional studies, cross over studies, non randomised controlled trials,prospective studies, uncontrolled trials. 

Types of study that will be excluded are: 
systematic reviews, meta analysis, case studies, animal research studies, cohort studies, case seriesstudies.

q13.value: N/A This is a systematic review with meta analysis

question.value:
Main outcomes include: 

Measures of cardiovascular health, measured as exercise intensity; %Heart Rate Reserve (%HRR) andwalking cadence (steps/min).

Additional outcomes include:
Walking intensity measured through; Relative intensity based metrics:
%Oxygen consumption reserve (%VO2r) 
%Peak Heart rate (%HRpeak) 
%Maximal Heart Rate (%HRmax) 
%Maximal Oxygen Consumption (%VO2max)
%Maximal Metabolic Equivalent (METmax)

Absolute intensity based metrics:
Metabolic Equivalent (METs)
Total step accumulation
Time spent in cadence bands based on METs (steps/min)

A narrative synthesis of the outcome measures, type of interventions including the specific details of the exercise prescription, methodology and supervision will be undertaken. The intention is to undertake a meta analysis of the data if the intervention and outcome methodology are not too heterogenous. If this is possible, then we will use a Bayesian random-effects approach to conduct the meta-analysis (Kruschke andLiddell, 2018). There are several advantages to this approach over traditional methods: (1) the ability to estimate between-study heterogeneity along with its uncertainty, (2) allocate more weight to the results of particular types of study (e.g. randomised controlled trials), (3) provide exact likelihoods, (4) allows for uncertainty in all parameters, (5) allows for other sources of evidence (e.g. prior distributions), and (6) allows direct probability statements using different measurement scales (Spiegelhalter, Abrams and Myles, 2004).Ultimately, the approach is to take the point estimate and standard error from individual studies and modelthese to produce an overall population Cohen’s d estimate for the effects of interest along with a measure ofbetween-study variability. Data modelling will be conducted using R (R Core Team, 2018). We will use brms,a package that uses Stan as the MCMC engine. Review Manager (Revman software) will be utilised topresent this analysis. If it is not possible to combine the results, we will present the quantitative results descriptively based on the values reported in the included studies. 


Kruschke, J. K., & Liddell, T. M. (2018). The Bayesian New Statistics: Hypothesis testing, estimation, meta-analysis, and power analysis from a Bayesian perspective. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 25(1), 178-206.Link: https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13423-016-1221-4

Spiegelhalter, D. J., Abrams, K. R., & Myles, J. P. (2004). Bayesian approaches to clinical trials and health-care evaluation (Vol. 13). John Wiley & Sons.

attributes.title: meta analysis study
attributes.description: Comparison of the Postoperative Analgesic Effects of Intrathecal Clonidine and Fentanyl as Adjuvant: Meta-Analysis of Randomized Control trials Study

q1.value: Comparison of the Postoperative Analgesic Effects of Intrathecal Clonidine and Fentanyl as Adjuvant: Meta-Analysis of Randomized Control trials Study

q3.value:
Spinal anesthesia with bupivacaine is the routinely done procedure for below umbilicus and lower limb Surgeries. This type of neuraxial anesthesia is ensuring intraoperative and early postoperative pain management despite the  restricted duration of action after surgical intervention. In turn,  adjuvant of intrathecal clonidine and opioids have been used to have a prolonged duration of analgesia and quality of blockage .  Different studies found that intrathecal midazolam, neostigmine, opioids and clonidine were associated with the extended subarachnoid blockage and reduction of postoperative analgesic consumption.
 Specifically, addition of low doses of  intrathecal clonidine and fentanyl could be linked with the lower incidence of adverse effects[8]. However, the intrathecal opioids with bupivacaine has been connected with side effects of nausea, vomiting, pruritus, respiratory depression and urinary retention. Amongst the opioids, fentanyl could be the choice of adjuvant because of its potency, rapid onset , shorter duration of action and lower  incidence of respiratory depression. Even though rising number of published trials with small number of patients, the harmonized and full up to date evidences in larger population is lucking so far on the post-operative analgesic effects of intrathecal clonidine versus fentanyl. 
Therefore, it was the aim of this Meta-analysis performed to confirm their conclusion using larger sample size.

q4.value: The primary outcome variable is duration of Analgesia. The secondary outcomes of interest are duration of sensory and motor blockage.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The trials included in our Meta-analysis: patients undergoing spinal anesthesia were assigned to at least two groups, including Clonidine alone as an adjuvant to local anesthetics and Fentanyl alone as an adjuvant to local anesthetics

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Data from qualified studies will be extracted independently by authors and summarized into a spreadsheet. Discrepancies were resolved by agreement. For each of the included studies, the following information were extracted; First author’s name, year of the study, numbers of patients/study participants, total volume for spinal anesthesia, and types of surgery

q13.value: since it is meta analysis study, it depends on the number of studies to be collected

q14.value: it is a meta analysis study .

question.value: The primary outcome variable was duration of Analgesia. The secondary outcomes of interest were duration of sensory and motor blockage.

A randomized effect model will be used to determine the outcomes of analgesic effects of clonidine and fentanyl adjuvant with 95% confident interval. We evaluated the heterogeneity of study results with the use of I2 test and random effect (RE) model

We will evaluate the heterogeneity of study results with the use of I2 test and random effect (RE) model. Significant heterogeneity will be considered P < 0.10 and I2 > 50% . The overall effect size of time of first analgesic request for intrathecal clonidine versus fentanyl was pooled by the forest plot with 95% CI.  The statistical analyses will performed by the use of Cochrane review manager (RevMan 5.3)

q21.value: Significant heterogeneity will be considered P < 0.10 and I2 > 50%

q22.value: if patients not undergoing spinal anesthesia were assigned to at least two groups, including Clonidine alone as an adjuvant to local anesthetics and Fentanyl alone as an adjuvant to local anesthetics

name.value: The Relation of Sleep Quality on CBT Outcomes for Social Anxiety Disorder

other.value:
Additional Exploratory Analyses: 
Do other sleep factors (i.e., sleep efficiency, sleep duration) before and after therapy sessions relate to treatment outcome between sessions?
Exploratory Aim: Explore whether sleep efficiency and sleep duration before and after therapy sessions, such that individuals with poor sleep efficiency and shorter sleep duration will be related to lower symptom severity. We will perform the same analysis used to test hypotheses 2 and 3.  

Do specific baseline sleep variables (i.e., sleep latency, sleep efficiency, sleep disturbances, medication use) relate to exposure therapy outcomes for SAD?
Exploratory Aim: Explore whether specific indices in the PSQI are predictive of treatment outcome for SAD.

sample.value: This study is a secondary analysis of an existing dataset of a from a multi-site RCT examining the dose-timing of DCS as an augmentation strategy for exposure therapy for social anxiety disorder. A total of 152 participants were randomized to the parent study. The total sample will be used to answer hypothesis 1. A truncated sample of 105 participants will be used to answer the remaining hypotheses. The truncated sample is due to failure to collect sleep data during the course of treatment. No additional data will be collected.

analyses.value: In order to investigate the relation to sleep and treatment outcome, multilevel modeling (MLM) will be used because it is the recommended method for analyzing longitudinal psychiatric data, accommodates missing data without requiring imputation, and includes all participants. Since there were 2 primary outcome variables (LSAS and SPD-S) we will perform a multivariate MLM (MMLM) as it reduces Type I error, increases power31, and avoids inconsistent findings. The 4-level MMLM analysis will consist of the 2 primary outcomes nested within repeated assessments over time, which were nested within individuals, which were nested within treatment cohort. Because inaccurate growth curve models (GCMs) can lead to incorrect results, we compared various GCMs and selected the log model since it demonstrated the lowest AIC and BIC. Treatment group was coded using 3 dummy variables. To equalize groups on baseline severity and to account for otherwise random error, baseline LSAS and SPD-S were included as covariates and the outcome variables in the MMLM were z-scored before analysis to equally weight them. Effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated as per Feingold.

dependent.value:
Social anxiety symptom severity: 

Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale (LSAS) was administered weekly prior to treatment session by trained independent evaluators blind to study condition. The LSAS is a 24-item scale that measures fear and avoidance in social and performance situations within the last week, using 0 (no fear/never avoids) to 3 (severe fear/usually avoids) scale.

Social Phobic Disorders-Severity Form (SPD-S) was assessed weekly prior to treatment session by trained independent evaluators blind to study condition. The SPD-S is the Clinical Global Impression Scale27 adapted for SAD, which instructs clinicians to use a 7-point scale (1=normal, not at all ill; 7=among the most extremely ill patients) to index the severity of social anxiety.

conditions.value:
This study is a secondary analysis of an existing dataset of a from a multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) examining the dose-timing of DCS as an augmentation strategy for a 5-session cognitive-behavioral group therapy (CBGT) for social anxiety disorder. Participants were randomized at session 2 in a double-blind fashion to one of four DCS medication groups (tailored, pre-session, post-session, or placebo). 
Specifically, participants were randomized to receive (1) placebo (PBO) before the session combined with DCS after a successful session or PBO after a non-successful session (Tailored); (2) DCS before the session combined with PBO after the session (Pre-session) (3) PBO before the session combined with DCS after the session (Post-session); or (4) PBO before the session combined with PBO after the session (Placebo). Participants received DCS or PBO during session 2-5.

hypothesis.value:
Question 1: Does baseline sleep quality (Pittsburg Sleep Quality Index, PSQI total score) relate to exposure therapy treatment outcomes for social anxiety disorder? 
Question 2: Does sleep quality prior to a therapy session relate to short-term treatment outcome between sessions?
Question 3: Does sleep quality after a therapy session relate to short-term treatment outcome between sessions?
Question 4: Does D-cycloserine (DCS), a medication shown to augment fear learning, moderate the relation between sleep quality and treatment outcomes?


Hypothesis 1: Pre-treatment sleep quality would predict treatment outcomes, such that lower baseline sleep quality would be associated with a slower decline in symptom severity over time and higher endpoint symptom severity. 

Hypothesis 2: Better subjective sleep quality prior to a therapy session (session x) would be related to lower symptom severity at the next session (session x+1) after controlling for symptoms at the previous session.

Hypothesis 3: Better subjective sleep quality after a therapy session (session x) would be related to lower symptom severity at the next session (session x+1) after controlling for symptoms at the previous session. 

Hypothesis 4: The relation between sleep quality and treatment outcome would be moderated by DCS administration, such that the relation would be weaker at session combined with DCS that at sessions combined with placebo.

study_type_other.value: This study is a secondary analyses of an existing dataset from a multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) that examined the dose-timing of DCS as an augmentation strategy for exposure therapy for social anxiety disorder.

attributes.title: Digital Literacy and Corrective Interventions to Reduce Fake News in India: A Field Experiment

q1.value: Digital Literacy and Corrective Interventions to Reduce Fake News in India: A Field Experiment

q5.value: The author would like to thank the Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI) at the University of Pennsylvania and the Judith Rodin Fellowship Fund. Thank you also to Sunai Consultancy, Patna for programming and implementing the survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Misinformation is a growing concern across the world and particularly in developing countries such as India, where false claims can distort public opinion, undermine faith in democracy and lead to violence. A host of academic studies have tested interventions to reduce fake news consumption across the world, however we lack empirical evidence about whether these measures work in India. Using a field experiment with 1200 respondents in Bihar, I ask: 1) Do strong fact-checking interventions increase respondents' ability to identify fake news? 2) How does motivated reasoning affect partisans' response to treatment? 3) Do targeted digital literacy campaigns impact respondents' ability to identify fake news? Treatment group respondents are given a flyer with corrections to four political fake news stories that went viral over WhatsApp during the 2019 election. The flyer also contains tools to help identify fake news. A survey enumerator spends 45 minutes with the respondent explaining each story on the flyer, how it was fact checked, and what the correct version is. The enumerator then demonstrates two tools to verify information: 1) how to navigate fact-checking websites; 2) how to reverse Google search an image. Respondents are randomly assigned to receive a flyer with pro-right wing fake news or anti-right wing fake news. After a two-week gap, we revisit the same respondents to measure the effect of this intervention on their ability to identify fake news. Respondents are shown a series of news stories varying in veracity, source, salience, and visual presentation. Two key DVs are measured: 1) perceived accuracy of each story, and 2) confidence in the identification of each story as fake or real. This is the first paper of its kind to explore the impact misinformation has on opinions, making it an important contribution to literature on political communication and polarization in India.

q16.value: Primary hypotheses: H1: Exposure to fact-checking will increase respondent ability to identify fake news relative to control. H2a: Exposure to fact-checking pro-BJP fake news will increase respondent ability to identify fake news relative to control H2b: Exposure to fact-checking anti-BJP fake news will increase respondent ability to identify fake news relative to control H3: Ability to identify fake news will be lower among those assigned to receive the pro-BJP treatment relative to those assigned to receive the anti-BJP treatment H4: Effectiveness of fact-checking will be higher for politically incongruent information compared to politically congruent information, relative to the control condition. Apart from these main hypotheses I also investigate several research questions for which I have weak theoretical priors (see attached pre-analysis plan for list).

q17.value: The experiment was conducted with a random sample of 1200 respondents in Bihar, India, in the context of the 2019 general elections. The experiment involves a baseline intervention phase and an endline measurement phase. The sample is divided randomly into three groups, two treatment and one control. Treatment-group respondents were shown a flyer that 1) fact checks four viral and salient fake news stories; 2) provides respondents with tips on how to combat fake news, including active demonstrations of techniques and tools for fact-checking. The intervention targeted to treatment group respondents is, by design, a bundled treatment designed to have a strong effect on fake news identification. It consists of a visit to a household by an enumerator and undertaking the following set of activities in a 30-40 minute visit: Introduction, measurement of pre-treatment covariates (digital literacy, political knowledge, media trust, information sources, priors), fact-checking flyer with enumerator debunking each fake story and providing tips on how to combat fake news, demonstrating to respondents how to reverse google search an image and showing respondents how to use a fact-checking website. Each household is revisited by the same enumerator for an end-line survey after two weeks. The main dependent variable measured during the endline survey measures respondents' actual ability to identify fake news as well as their confidence in this ability. This study was conducted in the city of Gaya and its suburbs in Bihar, India. The sample is predominantly urban and I pre-condition the sample to respondents who have had access to a smartphone with internet for at least the last six months and have downloaded and been using WhatsApp on their phones. Sampling in this paper follows a random walk procedure (for more detail on study design and procedures see attached pre-analysis plan).
